patterns.description: Threatens arrest with a warrant — the CRA will never threaten arrest by phone.
Generic arrest warrant language commonly used in CRA phone scams.

patterns.pattern: you (owe|have an outstanding balance of) \$?[0-9,.]+ to (the )?(canada revenue agency|\bCRA\b)
patterns.description: Claims you owe a specific dollar amount to CRA — real CRA sends written notices first.

patterns.pattern: you (must|need to) pay (immediately|today|within 24 hours) (or|otherwise) (you will|we will) (be arrested|go to jail|be deported)
patterns.description: Demands immediate payment under threat of arrest, jail, or deportation.

patterns.pattern: (gift cards?|itunes|apple cards?|google play|prepaid credit cards?).*(pay|settle|clear) (your )?(tax|cra) debt
patterns.description: Demands CRA tax payment via gift cards — the CRA never accepts gift cards.
Demands CRA payment via cryptocurrency or Bitcoin ATM.
Instructs victim to use a Bitcoin ATM for payment — the CRA never does this.

patterns.pattern: climate action incentive|climate action refund|CAI payment|climate incentive
patterns.description: References the Climate Action Incentive — a common phishing pretext since Oct 2025.
CRA refund phishing — offers a specific refund amount with a link to claim it.
Offers a GST/HST tax refund — real refunds come through direct deposit, not links.

patterns.pattern: emergency (benefit|relief|disaster payment) from (cra|canada revenue agency|the government)
patterns.description: Uses emergency/disaster benefit pretext to harvest personal information.
Requests your SIN — the CRA will never ask for your full SIN by phone, text, or email.
Threatens that RCMP officers are being sent — the CRA does not dispatch police.
Claims CRA refund via Interac e-Transfer — the CRA never sends refunds by e-Transfer.
